conclusion: Introduction to the problem and PV diagram description.
The x-axis is volume in liters (L), and the y-axis is pressure in atmospheres (atm). Points A, B, and C are plotted.
Point A: V = 1 L, P = 4 atm; Point B: V = 3 L, P = 3 atm; Point C: V = 4 L, P = 1 atm.
Use of the ideal gas law PV = nRT.
Convert temperature at state A from Celsius to Kelvin: T_A = 400.15 K.
Set up the ratio (P_B * V_B) / (P_A * V_A) = T_B / T_A.
Plug in known values to the ratio and calculate: (9) / (4) = 2.25.
Convert T_B from Kelvin to Celsius: 900.34 K - 273.15 = 627.19°C.
Consider if the process is isobaric, isochoric, or adiabatic.
From A to B, pressure decreases from 4 atm to 3 atm, and volume increases from 1 L to 3 L.
Determine it doesn't look like an isobaric, isochoric, isothermal, or adiabatic process.
Decide to stick with the general ideal gas law approach.
